currentDoc:
Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not. 
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not. 
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, libretaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human on human violence, than 

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not. 
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal. 

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not. 
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal. 

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.

I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal. 

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.  

This may be the

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal. 

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.

It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.  

The

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not. 
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal. 

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not. 
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal. 

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.  

The complexity of the humans m

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not. 
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal. 

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.  

The complexity of the humans makes all the difference.

It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.  

The complexity of the humans makes all the difference. Humans widely

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not. 
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal.

 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal. 

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.  

The complexity of the humans makes all the difference. Humans widely accept animals as food,

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.  

The complexity of the humans makes all the difference. Humans widely accept animals as food, or clothing. B

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not. 
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal.

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not. 
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal. 

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.  

The complexity of the humans makes all the difference. Humans widely accept animals as food, or clothing. But any other useless viol

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not. 
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal. 

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.  

The complexity of the humans makes all the difference. Humans widely accept animals as food, or clothing. But any other useless violence is more easy t

It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.  

The complexity of the humans makes all the difference. Humans widely accept animals as food, or clothing. But any other useless  violence is more easy to be seen as just that.

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not. 
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not. 
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal. 

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.  

The complexity of the humans makes all the difference. Humans widely accept animals as food, or clothing. But any other useless or senseless violence is more easy to be seen as just that.  With hu

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not. 
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal. 

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.  

The complexity of the humans makes all the difference. Humans widely accept animals as food, or clothing. But any other useless or senseless violence is more easy to be seen as just that.  With humans, there's a cloud o

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not. 
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal. 

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.  

The complexity of the humans makes all the difference. Humans widely accept animals as food, or clothing. But any other useless or senseless violence is more easy to be seen as just that.  With humans, there's a cloud of uncertaint

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not. 
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal. 

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.  

The complexity of the humans makes all the difference. Humans widely accept animals as food, or clothing. But any other useless or senseless violence is more easy to be seen as just that.  With humans, there's a cloud of uncertainty that lingers of many

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not. 
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal. 

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.

 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal. 

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.  

The complexity of the humans makes all the difference. Humans widely accept animals as food, or clothing. But any other useless or senseless violence is more easy to be seen as just that.  With humans, there's a cloud of uncertainty that lingers of many interpersonal actions, and this makes al

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.  

The complexity of the humans is . Humans widely accept animals as food, or clothing. But any other useless or senseless violence is more easy to be seen as just that.  With humans, there's a cloud of uncertainty that lingers of many interpersonal actions, and this makes all the difference.

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not. 
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal.

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not.  I
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal. 

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.  

The complexity of the humans is the key difference. Humans widely accept animals as food, or clothing. But any other useless or senseless violence is more easy to be seen as just that.  With humans, there's a cloud of uncertainty that lingers of many interpersonal actions, and this makes all the difference.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not.  If we do not speak 
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal. 

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.  

The complexity of the humans is the key difference. Humans widely accept animals as food, or clothing. But any other useless or senseless violence is more easy to be seen as just that.  With humans, there's a cloud of uncertainty that lingers of many interpersonal actions, and this makes all the difference.

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not.  If we do not speak for them, nobody w
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal. 

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.  

The complexity of the humans is the key difference. Humans widely accept animals as food, or clothing. But any other useless or senseless violence is more easy to be seen as just that.  With humans, there's a cloud of uncertainty that lingers of many interpersonal actions, and this makes all the difference.

The complexity of the humans is the key difference. Humans widely accept animals as food, or clothing. But any other useless or senseless violence is more easy to be seen as just that.  With humans, there's a cloud of uncertainty that lingers of many interpersonal actions, and this makes all the difference.

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not.  If we do not speak for them, nobody will. 
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal. 

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries.  It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal. 

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.  We can all judge th

The complexity of the humans is the key difference. Humans widely accept animals as food, or clothing. But any other useless or senseless violence is more easy to be seen as just that.  With humans, there's a cloud of uncertainty that lingers of many interpersonal actions, and this makes all the difference.

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not.  If we do not speak for them, nobody will. 
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal. 

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.  We can all feel the l

The complexity of the humans is the key difference. Humans widely accept animals as food, or clothing. But any other useless or senseless violence is more easy to be seen as just that.  With humans, there's a cloud of uncertainty that lingers of many interpersonal actions, and this makes all the difference.

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.  We can all feel the loss when somethin

The complexity of the humans is the key difference. Humans widely accept animals as food, or clothing. But any other useless or senseless violence is more easy to be seen as just that.  With humans, there's a cloud of uncertainty that lingers of many interpersonal actions, and this makes all the difference.

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not.  If we do not speak for them, nobody will. 
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not.  If we do not speak for them, nobody will. 
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal. 

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.  We can all feel the loss when something we own is damage

The complexity of the humans is the key difference. Humans widely accept animals as food, or clothing. But any other useless or senseless violence is more easy to be seen as just that.  With humans, there's a cloud of uncertainty that lingers of many interpersonal actions, and this makes all the difference.

In my opinion, it is not wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering. In fact, it is important to do so. Animals are more vulnerable to suffering than humans. Humans have many people speaking for them, while animals do not.  If we do not speak for them, nobody will. 
I think that people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals because they are not as complex as humans.
 It is easier to relate to the suffering of animals. Humans are more complex and it is harder to relate to them. Human interactions have ambiguity. Is the striking in self-defense, spanking, liberation of a country's people or oil, retaliation for cheating? There's many more questions and contexts to human-on-human violence, than human-on-animal. 

There's a large body of social context to animal empathy.  Nearly every culture has been taught to fear "outsiders" or other countries. It is easier to fear a stranger than it is to empathize with them.  With animals, many societies view them as lesser beings, tools or objects that we own. It is easier to empathize with something that we own than it is to empathize with a stranger.  We can all feel the loss when something we own is damaged. 

The complexity of the humans is the key difference. Humans widely accept animals as food, or clothing. But any other useless or senseless violence is more easy to be seen as just that: uneeded abu.  With humans, there's a cloud of uncertainty that lingers of many interpersonal actions, and this makes all the difference.

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.
